message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined oral contraceptives containing both a progestin and estrogen work primarily by suppressing the mid-cycle surge of luteinizing hormone (LH), thereby inhibiting follicular rupture and ovulation. Thickening of cervical mucus and suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis are also mechanisms of action, but inhibiting the rise in LH is the most important. Increase in sex-hormone binding globulin is a secondary effect of the medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined oral contraceptives work by inhibiting the rise of luteinizing hormone (LH), therefore inhibiting ovulation. While thickening of cervical mucus and suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis are also mechanisms of action, inhibition of LH rise is the most important in the prevention of pregnancy. Increase of sex-hormone binding globulin is a side effect of combined oral contraceptives.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol tablets are a type of combination hormonal contraceptive. The most important mechanism of action is the inhibition of rise in luteinizing hormone, which prevents ovulation. Thickening of cervical mucus also plays a role in preventing sperm from reaching the egg, but it is not the most important mechanism. Suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis and increase of sex-hormone binding globulin are also effects of the drug, but they are not mechanisms of action in preventing pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined oral contraceptives containing levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol work by inhibiting the rise in luteinizing hormone, which prevents ovulation. Thickening of cervical mucus and suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis also contribute to the contraceptive effect, but inhibiting the rise in luteinizing hormone is the most important mechanism of action. Increase of sex-hormone binding globulin is a side effect of some oral contraceptives, but it is not the mechanism of action for preventing pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol tablets work mainly by inhibiting the rise in luteinizing hormone, which prevents ovulation and follicle development. Thicker cervical mucus is a secondary effect that may impede sperm transport, and increased sex-hormone binding globulin is a side effect of estrogen use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol tablets work by inhibiting the rise in luteinizing hormone, preventing ovulation. Thickening of cervical mucus can also contribute to the prevention of pregnancy, but it is not the most important mechanism of action. Suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis and increase of sex-hormone binding globulin are also effects of this drug, but they are not related to its contraception properties.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol tablets suppress the release of luteinizing hormone, which in turn prevents ovulation and therefore pregnancy. Thickening of cervical mucus and suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis are also mechanisms of action, but they are not the most important. Increase of sex-hormone binding globulin is not a mechanism of action of oral contraceptives.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined oral contraceptives like levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol work by inhibiting the rise in luteinizing hormone, which prevents ovulation. Thickening of cervical mucus makes it more difficult for sperm to reach the egg. Suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis also prevents ovulation. Increase of sex-hormone binding globulin decreases the levels of free testosterone, but this is not the primary mechanism of action for preventing pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined oral contraceptives work through several mechanisms, but the most important one is the inhibition of the rise in luteinizing hormone, which prevents ovulation from occurring. Thickening of cervical mucus and suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis also contribute to its contraceptive effect, but to a lesser extent. Increase of sex-hormone binding globulin occurs as a result of the medication, but it is not a mechanism of action for its contraceptive effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combined levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol tablets work mainly by inhibiting the rise in luteinizing hormone, which therefore inhibits ovulation. Thickening of cervical mucus can also help prevent pregnancy, but it is not the most important mechanism for this drug. Suppression of ovarian folliculogenesis and an increase in sex-hormone binding globulin are also mechanisms of action of this drug, but they are not the primary mechanism for preventing pregnancy.
